title: Barclays in discussions to end 2008 fraud probe
text:

Tue, Jul 21, 2015, 14:36 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 54 mins Barclays in discussions to end 2008 fraud probe By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 7 minutes ago 282.35 +1.500 
The bank could accept a Serious Fraud Office deferred prosecution agreement to end the investigation into its £2bn Qatari fundraising in 2008 
Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) is understood to be considering whether or not to accept a deferred prosecution agreement with the Serious Fraud Office, which would draw something of a line under the lengthy investigation into the bank's £2bn Qatari fundraising in 2008. 
Neither the bank nor the fraud squad would comment on the existence or otherwise of a deferred prosecution agreement (DPA), first reported by Sky News . 
But sources with knowledge of the situation indicate such an agreement would typically come with tough terms and conditions as well as a fine, and as such the bank has yet to decide if it should agree. 
Britain's regulators have only recently gained the power to offer DPAs. Typically they do not require the bank to accept responsibility, instead settling the case with a payment and imposing monitors at the institution subject to the agreement. 
However, if the bank does agree to the DPA, it will only cover the bank rather than any individuals who worked for Barclays. 
It is not the first time the bank has considered reaching such a deal with regulators. 
Barclays agreed to a non-prosecution agreement with US authorities over the Libor manipulation scandal in the summer of 2012. In that deal the bank admitted misconduct, paid $160m to the Department of Justice and agreed to help fraud investigators to the fullest extent possible in their probes into the bank. 
The two-year agreement was extended last year in light of the looming foreign exchange benchmark investigations. 
The SFO launched the probe in the summer of 2012 , looking into payments around the bank's £2bn fundraising in 2008. Barclays raised the money in the financial crisis to give it the extra financial firepower it needed to survive, while rivals Lloyds and RBS (LSE: RBS.L - news ) were bailed out by the taxpayer instead. 
The deal was followed by a further £6.8bn fundraising in the Middle East, and fees totalling £300m caught the attention of the authorities.
